loans.name: Mary Anne

texts.en:
Mary Anne L. is from the village of Calaocan, Alicia, Isabela. She is 30 years-old and married with two small children. Mary Anne owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Mary Anne has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Mary Anne joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Anne is requesting a first loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products.

loans.name: Amarjargal

texts.en:
Amarjargal is 46 years old and a single mother. She lives with her three children in a house in Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. Her oldest two children began to work in order to help with the family's living expenses. The oldest one used to manage a meat trading business with her mother, while the second works as a waiter at a little restaurant. Her 16-year-old son is in a local secondary school.

Amarjargal operates a meat trading business in her town. She started her business in 1994 after graduating from her university as a bakery technician. She is a hard worker and has used her good management skills to grow her business over the last 15 years. Now her working capital exceeds 800,000 tugrugs (~560 USD), with monthly net profit of 400,000 tugrugs (~280 USD).

She is always planning for the future and hopes to expand her meat trading business. She hopes she will attract new customers and increase her earnings. Amarjargal is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~350 USD) loan to purchase more meat to sell in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah is 38 years old and married with a child. His wife sells foodstuffs to support her home.

Elijah loves baking and that is why he commercialized his baking skills. He bakes loaves of bread to sell at wholesale and retail prices to his customers. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He hopes to own a catering school in the future.

Elijah hopes for a loan of NGN 160,000 to purchase more bags of flour to bake more loaves of bread to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more flour to bake more loaves of bread to sell

loans.name: Budragchaa

texts.en:
Budragchaa is 50 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Zavkhan province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His youngest son goes to university.

During the winter, Budragchaa works at a private company as a security guard in his town. In summertime, he makes traditional Mongolian shoes by hand. In order to supplement his earnings, sometimes he also makes deel, which is a traditional Mongolian coat.

Budragchaa has been making shoes for many years now. His shoes are well known and valued by his customers for their quality and design. He sells his shoes for 60,000-80,000 tugrugs (~42-56 USD) and receives between 50-60% net profit for each pair. Budragchaa would eventually like to expand his little shoe-making shop into a factory employing several people. He is requesting a 400,000 tugrug (~280 USD) loan to purchase materials such as glue, leather, rubber, and tools for his shoe-making business.

loans.use: To purchase materials such as glue, leather, rubber and tools

She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC. Elueteria is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This will be her 2nd loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Dolgorjav

texts.en:
Dolgorjav is 32 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Arkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.  His oldest son attends the local secondary school while the youngest has not reached school age. 

Dolgorjav operates a raw material trading business in his local market. He began the business in 2000 and continues to trade raw materials such as sheep and goat skins to local retailers. At first his working capital was 500,000 tugrugs (~350 USD). This business is the only source of income for Dolgorjav’s family and he is determined to expand his customer base and product offerings in order for his family to become financially secure. Now his working capital exceeds 3,000,000 tugrugs (~2100 US). He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan to purchase more sheep and goat skins for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more sheep and goat skins

loans.name: Nehemia's Group

texts.en:
Nehemia C. is from the village of Diamantina, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 43 years old. Nehemia is the group leader of an eighteen-member group loan offered by the Kiva field partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.The official name of this borrower's group is Nehemia C.' Group.

Nehemia is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she runs a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Nehemia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 500 PHP daily.

In 2007, Nehemia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Nehemia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Princess Felicia

texts.en:
Princess Felicia is a widow with 6 children. She is 56 years old. She is a hard-working woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She sells tailoring materials and she also sews lovely designs for her customers. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to own a fashion home in the future.

She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 170,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David M. O. is 25 years old. He is married and has two children. His wife is a business lady.

David's business is located at Harambee-Kakamega where he engages in passenger transportation services as well as selling cereals to the local people. David is using this loan to buy cereals to expand his business. In the future, he hopes to buy more motorbikes and a matatu, and to open a store to supply to a bigger market. He is a God-fearing and determined person.

loans.use: To buy cereals to sell

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda B. is presently residing at Susayan, Dalaon, Molave, Zamboanga del Sur and is married with three children.

Florenda is a vegetable vendor at Molave public market. She has been engaged in her business for more than seven months and earns 6,000 a month. It is not the only means of generating revenue since her husband is a farmer and is also supporting the family.

Florenda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid her previous loan of 4,000 PHP. This loan was used to invest in expanding her business.

Florenda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will again be use to invest in expanding her business. This will be the her 2nd loan from PMPC.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Nwaiwu

texts.en:
Nwaiwu is 57 years old and married with a child. His wife sells foodstuffs to support her home.

Nwaiwu loves groceries and that is why he sells groceries. He sells groceries at wholesale and retail prices to his customers. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He hopes to own a supermarket in the future. He hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a widow with 4 children. She is 61 years old. She is a hard-working woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty.

Florence sells ice blocks to customers. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more materials to make more ice blocks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more materials to make more ice blocks to sell

loans.name: H. Akouavi Bernadette

texts.fr: Z. H. Akouavi Bernadette est née en 1953 à Allada, dans la commune de l'Atlantique au Bénin. Akouavi Bernadette vit depuis près de 15 ans à Dodomey à Allada. Mariée à AGUENON Paul, Akouavi Bernadette est mère de deux enfants. Akouavi Bernadette a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de ses enfants. Seulement certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Akouavi Bernadette n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour venir en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille, Akouavi Bernadette vend des bois de chauffage à son domicile. Akouavi Bernadette mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de "sodabi" (boisson alcoolisée locale). Akouavi Bernadette exerce cette activité depuis trente ans. C'est dans les villages de Allada que Akouavi Bernadette s'approvisionne. Akouavi Bernadette a bénéficié déjà de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, et les a bien remboursés. Dans l'optique d'agrandir son activité et se faire une épargne qui servira à l'éducation de ses enfants, Akouavi Bernadette sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Akouavi Bernadette envisage plus tard construire sa propre maison.
texts.en:
H. Akouavi Bernadette Z. was born in 1953 in Allada, Benin's Atlantic community. Akouavi Bernadette has been living in the Dodomey area of Allada for the past 15 years. She is married to Paul AGUENON, and mother of two. Akouavi Bernadette has another child under her care, in addition to her own children. Only some of her children are educated. The couple share household expenses. Akouavi Bernadette has not attended school. To assist her husband with the household expenses, Akouavi Bernadette sells firewood from her home. As a secondary business, she also sells "sodabi" (a local alcoholic beverage). Akouavi Bernadette has been performing these activities for the past 30 years. She gets her supplies from the villages of Allada. Akouavi Bernadette has already been granted two loans by ALIDé, which she has fully reimbursed. With the view of increasing her activity and putting money aside for her children's education, she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé. In the future, Akouavi Bernadette considers building her own home.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 20 loads of firewood and twenty 50-litre drums of "sodabi"

loans.name: Eniola

texts.en:
Eniola is a widow with 2 children. She is 56 years old. She is a hard-working woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty.

Eniola sells crates of drinks to her customers. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 170,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Adedeji

texts.en:
Adedeji is 39 years old and married with 3 children. His wife is a tailor and she supports her home.

Adedeji loves shoes and that is why he makes and sells shoes. He sells shoes at wholesale and retail prices to his customers. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He hopes to own a shoe factory in the future. He hopes for a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more leather to make more shoes to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more leather to make more shoes to sell

loans.name: Aïssetou

texts.fr: T. O. Aïssetou est née le 30 Août 1971 à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin. Aïssetou vit depuis environs 15 ans à Dodomey à Allada. Mariée à ANAGO Benoît, un technicien de laboratoire, Aïssetou est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Aïssetou a fréquenté jusqu'au cours secondaire. Il y a cinq ans de cela, pour venir en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille, Aïssetou vend des cartes de recharges téléphoniques et des accessoires de portables (battéries, chargeurs, etc.) à Allada. Aïssetou vend également des divers (bombons, piles, savons de toilette, allumettes, stylos, etc.) dans sa boutique. Aïssetou s'approvisionne à Allada, et aussi à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Aïssetou a déjà obtenu deux fois de crédits à Allada, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Aïssetou désire élever davantage le niveau de son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle ; cependant, Aïssetou ne dispose pas encore d'assez de moyens financiers pour y arriver. C'est la raison pour laquelle Aïssetou sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Aïssetou ambitionne devenir plus tard grossiste.
texts.en:
Aïssetou T. O. was born on August 30, 1971, in Allada, in the Atlantique Department in Benin. For about 15 years, Aïssetou has been living in the Dodomey area in Allada. She's married to Benoît ANAGO, a laboratory technician. She's the mother of two school-attending children. The couple takes care of all family expenses together. Aïssetou attended school up to secondary level.

In order to help her husband with the family expenses, Aïssetou has been selling telephone recharge cards and mobile phone accessories (batteries, chargers, etc.) for five years in Allada. Aïssetou also sells various items (candies, batteries, soaps, matches, pens, etc.) in her shop. Aïssetou gets her supplies in Allada, and also in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.

Aïssetou already benefited from two loans in Allada, which were repaid without problems. She wishes to bolster her business to better meet customer demand. However, she does not have sufficient financial means to achieve this goal. This is why Aïssetou is seeking a third loan from Kiva's partner, Alidé. She ambitions to later become a wholesaler.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy phone accessories (batteries, chargers, phone recharge cards)

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
37-year-old Juliet is married with four children. Her husband sells electronics to support the family while she sells hair products. She enjoys selling hair extensions and making lovely hair styles for her customers. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction with her customers.  Juliet is a hard working woman hoping to lift her business and family above poverty. 

She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 170,000 to purchase more hair extensions. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions

loans.name: Kiyomiddin

texts.en:
Kiyomiddin has worked as a barber for many years. He is very talented and that’s why he has so many clients. Also, he doesn’t charge much for his services. At the same time, he is engaged in the business of raising and selling cattle. Now Kiyomiddin wants to borrow money so he can buy newer instruments for hair cutting and also young cattle. This way he thinks he can offer a better service for his clients as well as expand his cattle-raising business.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase newer instruments with better technology.

loans.name: Mrs. Mao Nhoem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan group consists of 21 people who live in Dak Por village in Takeo province. Mrs. Mao N., a 37 year old mother of four, is the elected village bank president. She is a silk weaver and a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Chhoy Pov, is a driver. One of her children is a silk weaver; two attend the local school; and one stays at home to do housework. 

Mrs. Mao N. is requesting a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase income and improve her family living conditions.  Mr. Pha K. did not come to take a loan but his wife is, so she is presented in the picture instead him.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Khudoyor

texts.en:
B. Khudoyor is 26 years old. He is a market vendor. He sells clothing at the central market of Dushanbe city. With his eight years of working at the market, Khudoyor has enough experience to do his work successfully, and he has clients who always come to him. He is trying to satisfy the needs of clients with various tastes and income levels.

Khudoyor wants to increase his working capital in order to purchase new goods to sell. For this reason, he is asking to borrow 4000 TJS. He promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all for supporting him. Your generosity can change his life. Be an important part of the growth of Khudoyor’s business. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new goods to sell

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en: Jennifer M. is a businesswoman from the Municipality of Molave Zamboanga Del Sur. When she started her food processing business, she began with limited capital. She joined Paglaum MPC to gain access to financial assistance to help improve her living situation and business situation. Her previous loan of 5,000 was used to expand her business. After having successfully repaid her previous loan, Jennifer is requesting a new loan of 7,000.00 to further expand her business. She plans to use the additional capital to improve her business and family living situation.

loans.use: Additional capital for food processing business

loans.name: Sylvain

texts.fr: W. Sylvain est né le 21 Décembre 1978 à Allada dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin. Sylvain est un divorcé et père de deux enfants, dont un est scolarisé. Sylvain vit seul avec ses enfants à Allomey à Allada, depuis environs 5 ans. C'est Sylvain seul qui assure les charges de sa famille. Sylvain a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire, et a appris ensuite la photographie. Depuis près de 8 ans, pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Sylvain mène l'activité de photographe et vend également des pellicules à Allada. C'est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin que Sylvain s'aqpprovisionne. Sylvain a obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, et l'a bien remboursé. Sylvain sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de l'institution, afin de renforcer son capital et d'acquérir un appareil photo numérique pour mieux satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
Sylvain W. was born on December 21, 1978, in Allada, in the Atlantique Department in Benin. Sylvain is divorced and the father of two children, out of which one attends school. For about five years, Sylvain has been living alone with his children in the Allomey area in Allada. Sylvain takes care of the family expenses on his own.

He dropped out of school at secondary level, and then got trained in photography. For about 8 years, Sylvain has been working as a photographer and selling photographic films in Allada, in order to take care of the family expenses. He gets his supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. He already benefited from one loan from Kiva's partner, Alidé, and repaid it without problems. He's seeking a second loan from the institution, in order to bolster his working capital and purchase a digital camera to better satisfy his customers.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a digital camera

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary, 48 years old, is married with four children. Her husband sells foodstuffs, while she sells mouth watery Nigerian food and drinks. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interactions with her customers. She is a hard working woman and wants to lift her business and family above poverty. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks

loans.name: Dilshod

texts.en:
D. Dilshod is married with five children. This is an average family in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. However, Dilshod is a unique entrepreneur. Together with his son he has been selling clothing in the central city market for about fifteen years. The secret of his success is simple: he tries not only to let his customers know the benefits of his products – he also creates a relationship with them, which brings them back again and again. However, he doesn’t want to stop where he is with his venture. Dilshod is seeking a loan of $2500 to re-stock merchandise in his store for the winter season. We believe that Dilshod’s desire to excel in pleasing his customers will determine his further success and encourage new customers to buy from him.

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to re-stock merchandise for the winter season

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.fr: S. Charlotte est née le 13 Octobre 1977 à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin. Il y a environs 32 ans que Charlotte vit à Allomey à Allada. Mariée à AGNIDE Marcellin, un électronicien, Charlotte est mère de deux enfants, dont un est scolarisé. Charlotte vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Allomey. Le couple assure ensemble les dépenses de la famille. Charlotte a été à l'école jusqu'au cours secondaire, puis a appris la couture. Charlotte mène cette activité depuis 8 ans. A côté de cela, Charlotte vend également des objets de mercerie (boutons, fermeture, etc.) dans son atelier à Allada. Charlotte s'approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Charlotte a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, crédit qui a été bien remboursé. Charlotte sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Charlotte S. was born on October 13, 1977, in the Atlantique Department in Benin. For about 32 years, Charlotte has been living in the Allomey area in Allada. She's married to Marcellin AGNIDE, an electronics technician. Charlotte is the mother of two children, out of which one attends school. She lives with her children and her husband in Allomey. The couple takes care of the family expenses together.

Charlotte attended school up to secondary level, and then learned sewing. Charlotte has been running this business for 8 years. In addition, Charlotte also sells sewing supplies (buttons, zippers, etc.) in her workshop in Allada. She gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Charlotte already benefited once from a loan from Kiva's partner, Alidé, which was repaid without problems. She's seeking a second loan from Alidé, in order to bolster her business and better meet customer demand.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies (buttons, zippers, thread, safety pins, etc.)

loans.name: Yalda

texts.en: Yalda, daughter of A. G., is 38 years old and married with two children. She operates a tailoring business from home with most of her clients being neighbors. She would like to take an individual loan of 14700 Afghani to buy sewing materials and a new sewing machine. Her old machine doesn’t work properly and she encounters many problems while sewing. She is confident she will repay her loan on time and thanks Kiva lenders for their support to entrepreneurs around Afghanistan.

loans.use: To purchase a new machine

loans.name: Bola

texts.en:
Bola is 53 years old and is a widow with six children. She is a hardworking woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty.

Bola sells drinks to make a living. This is the high season for business and she hopes to make more profits during this season. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers.

Bola hopes to expand her business in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 170,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Begmat

texts.en:
Begmat is a hard-working person, and he makes an effort to give his 4 beloved children the best. He decided to stay in his home land so that he could develop it, and now he carries out his everyday chores with a lot of love and affection as he cultivates the land and feeds his animals. With experience gained over 20 years in the purchase and sales of cattle, Begmat has been able to bring stability to his family.

Begmat would now like to purchase more cattle to create more income for his large family. For this reason he requests 6000 Somoni. Begmat thanks you very much for your love of the prodigal.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand his business

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les  cinq membres du groupe Djekafo sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 50 ans et 6 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans la ville de Fana, quartier Fana coura, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage, de parentés et  exercent le commerce d’articles divers (jus, céréales, tissus, friandises, produits alimentaires etc.) 
Ce groupe de femmes collabore avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de satisfaire leur clientèle qui ne cesse d’accroître du jour en jour. Elles sont à leur deuxième  prêt solidaire après avoir   remboursé le premier. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, 2 sacs de 100Kg de haricot qui sera transformé en baignés, des sacs de patates douces pour la préparation des friandises et 200Kg de gingembre qui sera transformé en jus. La vente de ces produits s’effectue exclusivement sur le marché de Fana à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 34 500FCFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The five members of this Djekafo group are married women with an average age of 50 and 6 children, on average. They live with their husbands and children in big traditional families in the town of Fana, Fana Coura neighborhood, sous-prefecture of Fana, Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali.

They met because of being neighbors or being related and they sell various items (juice, cereal, cloth, snacks, foodstuffs, etc.) This group of women has been working with Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy their clientele which continues to grow from day to day. They are on their second solidarity loan, after having reimbursed the first one.

With this new loan, they expect to buy 2 sacks of 100 kg of dried beans which they will make into fritters, sacks of sweet potatoes for use in making snack foods, and 200 kg of ginger which will be made into juice. They sell these products exclusively in the marketplace of Fana to a clientele composed of women and men.

They each expect to make an average profit of 34,500 F CFA monthly. Part of the profit will be reinvested in their businesses and the rest used for daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of ginger, sweet potatoes, and dried beans

loans.name: Marohat

texts.en:
G. Marohat is a 32-year old married woman. She and her husband have a little son. Marohat and her husband are dreaming that their dearest child will have a bright future.

Marohat sells meat products like sausages, boiled sausage, and frankfurters, and dairy products such as cheese, butter, and mayonnaise. She has been in this business for 15 years. Marohat is a very polite and cheerful woman by her nature. That is why she has her bulk buyers, which allows her to earn a stable income for her family.

Today Marohat requests $1000 USD as she is planning to purchase more meat products in order to meet her clients' demand. She sincerely thanks all her lenders for supporting her and for the great job that they are doing for her!

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase meat products to expand the range of goods she sells

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Djiguisseme sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans la ville de Fana, quartier Fana coura, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parentés et exercent  le commerce d’articles divers (habits, chaussures, encens, condiments alimentaires etc.)
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse et exigeante,  ce groupe de femmes décida de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire et les quatre prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 100Kg de graine d’encens, 5 à 10 pièces de bazin, 50 à 100 paires de chaussures en plastique et une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires (trois sacs de 50Kg d’oignon, des poivres, des cubes maggi,  des spaghettis et des boites de concentrée de tomate). La plupart de ces marchandises est acheté à Bamako et sont revendus au marché de Fana et aux domiciles des femmes à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 22 500FCFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille. 
Elles ambitionnent de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités génératrices de revenus telle que la teinture.
texts.en:
The six members of this Djiguisseme group are married women with an average age of 40 and on average, 4 children. They live in big traditional families with their husbands and children in the town of Fana, Fana Coura neighborhood, Sous-prefecture of Fana, Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali.

They met through being neighbors and/or being related to each other, and they sell various items (clothing, shoes, incense, condiments, etc.) So as to satisfy their ever-growing and ever more demanding clientele, this group of women decided to work with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their 5th solidarity loan, and their four preceding loans were correctly reimbursed. With this loan they expect to buy 100 kg of incense grains, 5-10 lengths of "bazin" (undyed damask cloth), 50-100 pairs of plastic shoes, and a large quantity of condiments (three sacks of 50 kg each of onions, peppers, Maggi cubes, spaghetti, and tins of tomato concentrate.)

Most of this merchandise is bought in Bamako and sold in the marketplace in Fana and out of the women's homes to a clientele made up of women and men. They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 22,500 F CFA. Part of the profit will be reinvested in their businesses and the rest used for daily family expenses. Their ambition is to diversify their businesses by taking up other money-earning activities such as dyeing cloth.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various items

loans.name: Sulton

texts.en:
N. Sulton is a hard-working, enterprising man who started his business two years ago so that he could have a better future. He buys and sells foodstuffs, and today he has an extensive clientele. Sulton understands the business very well, so he has had great success. He hopes to keep expanding the business and increasing sales daily. He hopes his business will help him improve his situation and his quality of life.

Sulton is asking for $1200 to stock his store, now that demand is increasing day by day. He is very grateful for your support in helping him expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to increase the range of goods he has to sell

loans.name: Adebola

texts.en:
Adebola is 41 years old and is married with two children. She is a hardworking woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty.

Adebola sells kerosene to make a living. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. This is the high season for business and she hopes to make more profits during this season.

Adebola hopes to expand her business in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 170,000 to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Pétronille

texts.fr: K. Pétronille est née le 31 Mai 1962 et vit depuis environs 23 ans à Sékou Centre à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin. Mariée à BOKOSSA Lucien, un instituteur à la retraite, Pétronille est mère de cinq enfants, dont trois sont à sa charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Pétronille a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et assurer les charges de la famille, Pétronille vend des habits et des chaussures à Sékou à Allada. C'est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, que Pétronille s'approvisionne. Pétronille exerce cette activité depuis 21 ans, et est à son deuxième crédit à ALIDé. Pétronille a bien remboursé le premier crédit qu'elle a obtenu de ALIDé. Pétronille sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé, dans le but d'agrandir son activité et de mieux satisfaire la demande de la clientèle.
texts.en:
Pétronille K. was born on May 31, 1962, and has always been living in the Sékou Centre area in Allada, in the Altantique Department in Benin. Married to Lucien BOKOSSA, a retired teacher, she's the mother of five children, and she has to support three of them. All children attend school. The couple takes care of the family expenses together. Pétronille dropped out of school at secondary level.

In order to provide for herself and her family, she sells clothes and shoes in the Sékou area in Allada. She gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She's been running this business for 21 years, and she's seeking her second loan from Kiva's partner, Alidé, in order to bolster her business and better meet customer demand.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 8 dozen shirts and 15 dozen shoes

loans.name: Asatulo

texts.en:
For the past 10 years, Asatulo has worked in agriculture, raising animals. He raises cattle, which he cares for greatly, since thanks to them, he can cover his household expenses. Asatulo showed us his animals with great happiness as his sheep were about to be vaccinated against the various sicknesses that affect that type of livestock.

For Asatulo, it is very important to work raising his animals, which is why he is currently seeking a loan in order to purchase additional cattle so that in future, he can earn more money. That will help his family to generate additional income. We appreciate your support for Asatulo’s projects.

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand his business

loans.name: Adenike

texts.en:
Adenike is a married with 2 children. She is 33 years old. She is a hard-working woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty.

Adenike sells medicines and groceries to make a living. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits during this season. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Iskandar

texts.en:
S. Iskandar is a loving and self-sacrificing son. Ever since he was very young, Iskandar has been around people raising animals, and thanks to this knowledge, he dedicates himself raising and selling cattle, work that he learned from his humble parents. With experience gained over time in the purchase and sales of cattle he has been able to bring stability to his family.

The desire that Iskandar harbors in his heart is that of increasing his capital to invest in acquiring more animals. By doing this, he can create more income for his family. He requests 4000 Somoni. Let’s get together behind the request of this devoted son to help him keep bringing well-being and security to the members of his family.

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand his business

loans.name: Kurbonmahmad

texts.en:
Kurbonmahmad is 58 years old and married. He lives with his wife. They have 7 children, who are almost all adults with their own families.

Several years ago, Kurbonmahmad opened a grocery store in their home, where he, with the help of his wife and children, sells all kinds of basic needs goods like sugar, pasta, flour, dairy, eggs, etc. His business is doing very well because it is located in an area where there is not much competition.

Kurbonmahmad is requesting a loan of 4400 Somoni that he plans to invest in the wholesale purchase of different foodstuffs. The demand for these products is very high and this will help him to increase his profits.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs to increase the range of goods he has to sell

loans.name: Lois

texts.en:
Lois is married with 4 children. She is 38 years old. She is a hard-working woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty.

Lois sells textbooks to make a living. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits during this season. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 170,000 to purchase more textbooks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more textbooks to sell

loans.name: Parviz

texts.en:
Y. Parviz is 24 years old. He sells DVD disks. He tries to have all the new movies, as well as concerts of the popular actors, singers and others. He also provides computer services such as audio editing of videotapes and discs with records of family events of his clients. Parviz tries to use modern, up-to-date technologies in his work so he can satisfy the demands and requirements of the customers. The business is successful in generating a good income for his family.

Today Parviz requests 5000 Somoni. He is planning to purchase a lot of DVD disks to increase the range of goods he has to sell. Parviz thanks all lenders who are supporting him and promises to be accurate in loan payment.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
